Neither can widows or orphans be compensated for the loss of their husbands and fathers. Thc part played by the Bureau of Mineral Resources. Geology and Geophysics in the search for oil may best be discussed under the headings of the different regions. The NorthWest Cape (or Carnarvon Basin) region ot Western Australia, had been examined and rejected by three major oil companies before the Bureau commenced geological surveys in the area. geological mapping of the whole of this basin and carried out detailed structural mapping of the Cape Range, Rough Range and GiraliaCardabia structures. Preliminary mapping of other structures was also carried out. The Geophysical section of the bureau made extensive reconnaissance and detailed gravity surveys in the North-west basin and pioneered the use of seismic methods in the area. The seismic survey proved that in one area at least the structure at surface did not extend to depth. This contribution by the bureau indicated conclusively to the company operating in the area that the selection of drilling sites could only be determinedby geophysical methods. A detailed gravity survey recently completed by the bureau on the Rough Range structure confirmed the results of the company's seismic survey which led to the selection of the first drilling site. As a result of the Bureau's work it was determined that the thickness of Permian sediments is 4,000 or 5,000 feet greater than was originally believed, and that older marine rocks of Devonian and Carboniferous age were also present beneath the Permian. As thc oil prospects of any area are proportional to the thickness of marine rocks present the results of the bureau's surveys were of great importance and led to the interest of the Caltex organization in the area. In the Kimberleys, thc wbole of the Fitzroy basin has been mapped in detail by the bureau, and discoveries were made of rocks of Ordovician, Triassic and Jurassic age. The bureau has demonstrated that o i l is present in the Ordovician rocks. Factors relating to oil potentialities have been determined and some structures mapped. Basic research on fossils, wlfich have an important place in the search for o i l , is also progressing. Detailed and reconnaissance gravity surveys are proceeding in this basin and local seismic surveys have been completed at one site, and are in progress at another. Asi n the North-west Cape region, work at Nerrima has shown that surface structures do not persist at depth and surface indications cannot be relied upon to define drilling targets. Extensive geophysical surveys have been made in the Roma district of Queensland in search of " buried ridge " structures in which there are good prospects of discovering commercial natural gas fields. In Papua, geological mapping has been done outside the limits of existing oil permits. This work is of importance in helping to understand the structure in the permit areas. In Victoria, near Sale, a small seismic survey was carried out. This followed earlier work with the airborne magnetometer near Lakes Entrance. A gravity survey was carried out in conjunction w i th thc airborne survey. In south-western Victoria a gravity reconnaissance survey has indicated areas which are suitable for further investigation.
